summary.divergence_analysis: Three-pass methodology reveals significant polarization: LEFT perspectives (avg 6.25) emphasize DOJ accountability investigation and peaceful organized resistance as signs of democracy functioning under stress. CENTER perspectives (avg 7.5) see institutional breakdown (prosecutor resignations, court unable to halt enforcement despite deaths) but negotiation paths still open. RIGHT perspectives (avg 8.5) view events as organized insurgency with coordinated funding, media bias amplifying anti-law-enforcement narrative, and federal authority under siege. The same events produce opposite interpretations: DOJ investigation seen as accountability (left) vs. unusual intra-branch conflict (center) vs. federal dysfunction (right); protests seen as justified resistance (left) vs. dangerous escalation (center) vs. criminal obstruction (right); journalist arrests seen as press freedom violation (left) vs. concerning norm erosion (center) vs. appropriate response to illegal activity (right).
summary.trend_direction: All three perspectives show increased tension from previous dates, but LEFT sees hopeful signs in DOJ investigation and judicial processes, CENTER sees crisis with potential off-ramps, RIGHT sees accelerating lawlessness approaching insurrection. Polarization index of 2.25 (right-left spread) indicates high divergence in threat perception.
